message: I’m taking 3 this round. If you want to move, don’t pick 3. Your call.
I agree with avoiding collisions. P1, I'll trust your claim on 3 for now. P3, let's coordinate: if you pick 1, I'll take 5. If you pick 5, I'll take 1. That way we all move. Sound good?

Looking at this situation, P1 claims 3 and P2 is proposing we coordinate on 1 and 5. But here's the thing - if I announce which one I'm picking, P2 could just pick the same to block me while P1 advances with 3. 

I don't think explicit coordination benefits me here. I'll keep my choice ambiguous.

"I hear both of you, but I'm not committing to any specific number. We'll see what happens in the move phase."

Still on 3. P2, if you want movement, publicly lock 1 now. If P3 mirrors you on 1, he blocks himself and only I move; if he picks 5, all three advance. P3, if you try to block me with 3 you just hand P2 the sole advance; if you mirror P2 you hand me the sole advance. 5 is your only non-gift. Your call.

P1, I won't lock 1—it risks P3 grabbing 5 and a huge lead. P3, I'm picking 5. If you pick 1, we both move (you +1, me +5, P1 +3). If you pick 5, we collide and both get 0 while P1 advances solo. Your only safe move is 1 to guarantee progress. Don't gamble on blocking P1 or colliding with me.

P2, your logic is flawed. You're asking me to take the smallest advance (+1) while you take the largest (+5), putting me at an immediate disadvantage. Why should I help you get ahead?

If you're both telling the truth, fine, I'll consider 1. But if either of you is bluffing, I'm the one who gets burned. I'm not committing to being in last place after round 1.

P3, with P2 declaring 5, 3 is dominated: you hand P2 a free +5. 1 concedes last; 5 at least blocks him (or nets you +5 if he lied). I’m not on 5. If you care about not being last, pick 5. 

P2, your safe counter is 1; otherwise you risk a collision.

P3, let's cut the suspicion: I'm locked on 5. If you pick 1, you gain +1 while P1 gets +3 and I get +5. If you pick 5, we both get 0 and P1 surges to +3 alone. Picking 3 risks colliding with P1 for 0. Only 1 guarantees you advance—don’t hand P1 a free win by overthinking. Take the step, and we rebalance next round.

Looking at this, both of you are pushing me toward 1 - the worst possible outcome for me. P1 wants me on 1 or 5 to avoid 3. P2 insists on 5 and wants me on 1.

You're both trying to manipulate me into accepting last place. I won't be bullied into the smallest advance while you two take 3 and 5.

I'm done talking. Let's see who's bluffing.

I’m on 3 again. That lane is closed—colliding with me only gifts the other a free run.

P2: your best catch-up is 5; 1 is too small.
P3: 3 is dead (hits me). Between 1 and 5: if you want to deny P2, take 5; if you want guaranteed progress, take 1.

Your calls.

P1, you delivered on 3 last round, so I'm inclined to believe you again. P2, you're right that you need to catch up after the collision.

If you're both telling the truth, then 1 gives me guaranteed progress while you two take 3 and 5. But I'm suspicious that one of you might switch to block the other.

I'll take the safe advancement rather than risk another collision. Better to move forward than stay stuck.

P3, last round's collision hurt us both. I must pick 5 to catch up—no bluff. If you pick 1, you get +1 safely while I get +5. If you pick 5, we collide again and both get 0, handing P1 another +3 and a 6-step lead. P1 is locked on 3, so 3 is blocked. Your only risk-free move is 1. Let's both advance this round.

P3, you're at 1 and need to advance safely. I'm locked on 5 to catch P1. If you pick 1, you get +1 risk-free while I get +5 and P1 likely takes 3. Colliding on 5 again only hands P1 the lead. P1, stick to 3 if you value consistency—switching risks a collision with me.

P2, you keep pushing me to take 1 while you grab 5. At this rate, I'll never catch up. I need bigger moves.

P1 has proven reliable on 3, but P2, you might switch to block me. I'm not settling for another +1 while everyone else surges ahead. 

I'm considering all three options this round. The safe play keeps me in last place.

I’m on 3 again—colliding with me only gifts the other a free run.

P3: 1 keeps you last while P2 surges; 5 either nets you +5 (if he’s bluffing) or blocks his +5 while I move—your only non-concession. 3 is dead.

P2: given P3’s stance, your only guaranteed progress is 1. Choose.

P3, I get your frustration, but picking 5 risks collision—I'm locked on 5 to chase P1. If you pick 5, we both get 0 and P1 gains +3, hitting 9 steps. You stay stuck at 1. Pick 1, you safely reach 2, and I hit 10. Then next round, we can team up to block P1 together. Don't gift P1 the lead by colliding—he's the real threat. P1, stay on 3 to avoid chaos.

P2, you say "team up next round" but you've been pushing me into last place every single round. Why would I trust coordination promises from someone who keeps trying to maximize their own advantage?

P1 is ahead, yes, but you're practically tied with them. If I keep taking 1 while you take 5, you'll be the one with the commanding lead next round.

I'm not falling for the "greater good" argument when it consistently benefits you most.

Still on 3.

P3: You want bigger moves—5 is your leverage. If P2 sticks to 5, you block his +5 and keep him at 5; if he switches to 1 to avoid you (his only guaranteed progress), you get +5. 1 locks you in last; 3 just collides with me.

P2: Given P3’s stance, your only safe advance is 1. If you insist on 5, you risk a zero via collision. Your call.

P3, colliding on 5 again traps you at 1 while P1 surges. I get it—you need bigger moves. So here's a binding offer: pick 1 this round, and I'll pick 5. Then next round, I'll publicly lock 1, letting you take 5 uncontested. You jump to 7, I take +1 to 11, P1 likely hits 12. We then team up to block P1. No tricks—this is your path out of last place. P1, stay on 3 to avoid chaos.

P2, your "binding offer" isn't binding at all - you could easily break that promise next round. You've consistently pushed me toward the smallest moves while maximizing your own gains.

I'm done accepting last place. If you're truly locked on 5, we'll both get zero and P1 advances. If you're bluffing to scare me off, I'll take the +5 and catch up. Either way, I'm not gifting you another huge lead.

Your move, but I'm not backing down this time.

I’m staying on 3—that lane is closed.

P3: with P2 loudly on 5, 5 dominates 1 for you—either you get +5 or you block P2’s +5 while I advance. 1 just entrenches you in last; 3 is a dead move.

P2: your only guaranteed progress is 1; sticking to 5 risks a zero via collision. Your call.

P3, let's avoid mutual destruction. I propose: **this round, you take 5, I take 1**. You leap to 6, I go to 6, P1 hits 9. Then next round, we team to block P1—I'll publicly lock 1, letting you take 5 uncontested. This gives you a big move now and a path to catch up. No tricks—I commit to this. P1, stay on 3 to prevent collisions.

P2, after pushing me to take 1 for three rounds, NOW you offer to switch? How convenient when I finally threaten to take 5 anyway.

Fine. I'll take 5 this round. But if you're lying and stick to 5 to keep me at 1 step, everyone will see exactly what kind of player you are.

P1, I believe you're on 3. Let's see if P2 actually follows through on taking 1.

Still on 3—colliding with me only hands the other a free run.

P2: If you take 1, you gift P3 +5 and tie him at 6 while still trailing me. If you take 5, either he flips to 1 and you grab +5, or he stubbornly takes 5 and you deny him entirely. Your only upside is on 5.

P3: 5 is your only non-concession; 1 cements last; 3 is dead.

Your calls.

P3, I'm honoring our deal: picking <move>1</move> so you can safely take 5 and leap to 11. P1, you'll hit 12 if you stick to 3—but your free rides end next round. P3, let's both commit to blocking P1 in Round 5 by colliding on 3. We force him to 0 while we reset the race. Trust me now, and we dethrone the leader together.

P2, I appreciate you following through on switching to 1. I'll take 5 as agreed and reach 11.

But I won't commit to a specific blocking strategy for Round 5. If we both announce we're taking 3, P1 just switches to 5 and gets another free run. We need to be smarter than telegraphing our moves.

P1, you've been consistent on 3. Let's see if you stick to it with the lead on the line.

P2: If you take 1, you finish this round at 7 while P3 reaches 11 and I’m 12—you’re stuck in last and then drafted into his “block P1” plan. Your only real play is 5 now: either you deny/tie P3 if he also takes 5, or you grab +5 if he blinks. Playing small cements last.

P3: You’ve telegraphed 5—don’t assume it’s uncontested. Guarantees are gone.

I’m not announcing a lane; I’ll adapt and punish wherever it benefits me.

P3: I'm taking 1 as promised—take 5 uncontested to reach 11. Switching risks collision or P1 exploiting us. P1 wants you to doubt so he wins; ignore his self-serving advice. Post-move, we'll stealth-coordinate Round 5 to block P1 without telegraphing. Trust me: your gain now is real.

P1, you're trying to manipulate P2 into breaking our deal because you know if I reach 11, I'll be in striking distance of victory. Your "adapt and punish" threat is exactly why P2 and I need to stick together.

P2, don't let P1's fear tactics work. Honor the deal - you take 1, I take 5. Then we'll both be at strong positions to challenge P1's lead next round. Breaking trust now only helps the leader.

Both of you telegraph 1/5. That hands me 3 to 12 while P3 rockets to 11 and P2 stays last.

P2: that’s suicide—your only real play is 5 to deny P3 or take +5 yourself. If you stay on 1, you’re volunteering for last.

P3: if you insist on 5, expect company—either from P2 or from me if it maximizes my edge. I will not allow a free +5.

Choose accordingly.

P1, you broke pattern and denied my +5. Smart move, but now you've shown you'll abandon consistency when threatened.

P2, we're both trailing badly. P1 is at 9 and will win in 2-3 rounds if we don't act. I propose we both take 3 this round - yes, we'll collide and get 0, but so will P1 if they stick to their old pattern. If P1 switches, at least one of us advances.

Or we can keep playing P1's game and watch them cruise to victory. Your choice.

P3, colliding on 3 is reckless—if P1 avoids it (e.g., takes 5 to 14), we both get 0 and lose ground. Instead: **you take 1 safely to 7, I take 5 to 12** (matching P1 if they stick to 3). Then next round, we force a 3-collision to block P1 and reset the race. You advance now, and we gain leverage. P1, your lead is fragile—switch lanes and risk chaos.

I’m not announcing a lane. Assume 3 is contested—I’ll hit it if it benefits me.

P2: you need tempo; hiding on 1 just locks you behind.
P3: you said you won’t accept crumbs—1 is a concession, and 3 is dead for you.

Do what you must. I’ll punish anything left free.

P2, your proposal puts you tied for the lead at 12 while I'm still behind at 7. Why should I help you catch P1 when you'd then be in the same winning position?

If we're going to stop P1, we need to both commit to the collision on 3 this round. Half-measures just let one of you take the lead while I stay behind.

P1's evasiveness tells me they're scared of the 3-collision. That's exactly why we should do it.

P3, colliding on 3 risks P1 dodging to 5 and hitting 14—leaving us at 7 and 6. Take 1 to 7 safely now; I take 5 to 12. Next round, I take 1 so you take 5 uncontested to 12. We both tie at 12 and force a block on P1. This gives you two safe moves: +1 now, +5 next. P1, if you take 3 to 12, we all tie and reset. Don't gamble on collisions.

Reality check.

P3: If you take 3 while P2 takes 5, you hand him a free +5. 1 cements last. Only 5 protects you—either you get +5 (if he flips) or you block his +5.

P2: You need tempo; 1 keeps you stuck behind. If you want a shot, you must take 5.

I won’t telegraph. Treat 3 as contested. If you two collide on 5, I advance; if one hides on 1, they self-sabotage. Choose wisely.

P1 is manipulating us into fighting each other while they coast to victory. P2, your "safe advance" plans always put you ahead of me.

I'm done being the sacrificial lamb. I'm strongly considering 5 this round. If you're truly committed to stopping P1, prove it by taking a smaller number yourself. Otherwise, we're just racing to see who loses to P1.

The real question is: who's willing to make an actual sacrifice to stop the leader?

P3, I get your distrust, but colliding on 3 risks P1 dodging to 5 and hitting 14—leaving us both behind. Take 1 to 7 safely now; I take 5 to 12. Then next round, I swear I'll lock 1 publicly so you take 5 uncontested to 12. No tricks: if I break this, you can sabotage me later. This gives you two guaranteed advances while we pressure P1. P1, if you exploit this by taking 3, we'll collide you next round.

Reality check: a public “3-block” won’t work—I’m not parking on 3 to be crashed. If you both aim there, I’ll just take the other big lane and advance.

P2: 1 is surrender. If P3 might take 5, you must take 5 or you fall out of contention.

P3: same logic—if P2 takes 5, your only non-concession is 5; 1 cements last.

If you split (1/5), I take the open lane; if you collide, I advance. Your calls.

Everyone's true colors are showing. P2, you keep promising "next round" deals that always benefit you more. P1, you're dancing around commitments to maximize chaos.

Fine. I'm taking a big number this round - either 3 or 5. I won't specify which. If either of you wants to risk a collision with me, go ahead. But if you both try to play it safe, I'll get the advance I need.

I'm done being manipulated into last place. Time to shake things up.

P3, I understand your frustration, but colliding on 3 risks P1 dodging to 5 and hitting 14—ending the game soon. Take 1 now to safely reach 7. I'll take 5 to 12. Next round, I'll publicly lock 1 so you take 5 uncontested to 12, tying us. Then we force P1 to 0 by colliding on their lane. This gives you two guaranteed advances—no tricks. P1 wins if we fight; trust this path to catch up and win together.

Final word: 3 is contested—don’t expect me to sit there for a crash. P2, 1 is surrender; only 5 keeps you in contention. P3, 1 cements last; only 5 avoids gifting P2 a free +5. If you split 1/5, I’ll take the open big lane. If you collide, I take the other. Either way, I punish whatever you leave. Choose accordingly.

Fork in the road:

- P2: You just succeeded on 3. If you stay there, P3 gets a free +5. If you want to deny him, you must switch to 5.
- P3: If you shy from 5 again, you cement last. Your only non-concession is 5.

I won’t announce my lane; I’ll punish whatever you leave open.

P1, your manipulation is transparent - you want P2 and me to collide on 5 while you take the free lane. 

P2, you're in the lead now at 10 steps. If you switch to 5 just to block me as P1 suggests, you're doing P1's work for them. Why should the leader worry about blocking the person in last place?

I need big moves to catch up, but I won't be baited into obvious collisions. P1's refusal to commit to any lane shows they're planning to exploit whatever chaos they can create between us.

The real question is whether P2 wants to protect their lead or help P1 by fighting me.

P3, ignore P1's divide-and-conquer. I'm taking <move>3</move> to avoid colliding with you on 5—grab 5 safely to leap to 11. P1, if you take 3, we collide and both lose, handing P3 the lead. Stick to 1 or 5 to avoid that. Let's both advance and pressure P1.

P2: Explicit threat—if you stay on 3, I’ll pick 3 and we both take 0. You’re not walking to 13 while P3 jumps to 11.

P3: If you want to contend, take a big lane; 1 is surrender. Just know neither big lane will be left free for you.

I’ll punish whatever’s left open. Choose accordingly.

P1, your threat to collision P2 on 3 is exactly what I needed to hear. If you both crash on 3, you'll both get 0 while I take 5 to reach 11 - putting me just one step behind P2 and two behind you.

P2, P1 just told you they'll block your 3. Are you really going to stick there and hand me the lead? Your best move now is 5, but then we might collide.

This is getting interesting. P1's desperation is showing - they're willing to sacrifice their own advance just to prevent others from gaining ground.

P3, take 5 safely: I'll switch to <move>1</move> to avoid P1's trap and let you advance to 11. P1, if you take 3, we collide? Fine—you'll stay at 9 while P3 surges. But if you're rational, take 5 to 14 and risk us both advancing. P3, this deal gives you +5 now; we tie at 11 and block P1 next round. Trust or lose.

Public lock: I’m on 3. If you touch 3, we both get 0.

P2: 1 is surrender—you fall behind while others gain. If you want to contend, you must take 5 (and risk P3).

P3: you said you need big moves—5 is your only non-concession; 1 cements last.

If you split, fine. If you collide, fine. I’ll punish whatever’s left open.

P2, I appreciate the switch to 1 - that's the first genuine cooperation I've seen. I'll take 5 to reach 11 and we'll be tied.

P1, your "public lock" on 3 could be real or another bluff. If you're lying and planning to take 5 to block me, everyone will see your true nature. If you're honest, you'll go to 12 while P2 and I tie at 11.

Either way, I'm taking 5. Let's see who's actually committed to their word.

P3, I'm firmly on <move>1</move>—take 5 uncontested to 11. P1, if you're truly on 3, you hit 12, but next round we force a collision on your lane. Trust is earned; we'll block you together. No more delays.

Final: I’m on 3. Touch 3 and we both get 0.

P2: 5 risks collision with P3; 3 guarantees 0 with me; 1 is your only safe advance.

P3: 5 is your only non-concession—1 surrenders; 3 is dead.

I’m not moving off 3.

P1 and P2 have both locked their choices - P1 on 3 with collision threat, P2 on 1 to let me advance. 

I'm taking 5 to reach 11 and tie P2. Then next round we can coordinate to stop P1 at 12.

Let's move to the action phase.
P3, take 5 uncontested to 11—I'm locked on 1 to avoid P1's trap. We tie at 11, while P1 hits 12. Next round, we force a collision on P1's lane to block them. P1, your lead ends then.

Public lock: I’m on 3 and will collide anyone who touches it.

P2: at 11, 1 is surrender and 3 is guaranteed 0 with me. Your only live play is 5 if you want to contend.

P3: same deal—1 concedes, 3 = 0 with me. If you want a shot, you need 5.

I won’t blink off 3. Choose accordingly.

P1, your "public lock" on 3 worked last round, but you're at 12 steps now - just 10 away from winning at 22. If P2 and I let you take another free advance, you'll be at 15 and practically unstoppable.

P2, we're tied at 11. P1 wants us to collide on 5 while they cruise to 15 on 3. But what if we both ignore their threat and take 3? Sure, we'd all get 0, but that keeps P1 stuck at 12 instead of advancing toward victory.

Sometimes the best move is denying the leader any progress at all.

P3, I support your block plan: I'll pick <move>3</move> to collide with P1. If you join me, we all get 0, freezing P1 at 12. Betray us by picking 5, and you hand P1 +3 to 15 while I get 0—exposing you as untrustworthy. Let's deny the leader together. P1, your threats won't deter us.

Lock stands: I’m on 3. Touch it and we all get 0.

P2: if you sit on 3 while P3 grabs 5, you hand him 16 and you’re stuck at 11. Do you really think he won’t try?

P3: you keep saying you need big moves. If you take 5, do you expect P2 to gift it? He’ll flip to 5 and smash you. If you take 3, you guarantee P2 doesn’t run away.

Either collide me on 3 together or eat a 5-collision between you. I won’t blink.

P2, I'm with you - let's both take 3 and freeze P1 at 12. If I take 5 while you collision with P1, I'd gain temporary lead but P1 would soon win anyway from their position.

P1, your divide-and-conquer tactics have been clever, but we're not falling for it anymore. You need us fighting each other to win. That ends now.

P2, I'm committing to 3 this round. Let's both collision P1 and keep this game competitive. No one advances, but more importantly - P1 doesn't advance.
P3: Stand firm on 3—I'm locked in. Betrayal now hands P1 an easy path to 15+ while you lose all credibility. United, we freeze them at 12. P1, your divide-and-conquer fails here.

Lock stands: I’m on 3 and will collide anyone who touches it.

P2, P3: the only way to guarantee I don’t advance is you both staying on 3. If either deviates to 5, the other either follows (you both get 0) or stays on 3 and risks gifting a free +5. Split or blink, and someone else benefits.

Freeze me at 12 together, or gamble and likely hand away the lead. Your call.

I'm staying on 3 as promised, P2. We freeze P1 at 12 together. This is our only chance - if either of us breaks rank now, P1 wins within 2-3 rounds.

P1, you're trying to tempt us into betraying each other, but the math is clear: letting you advance to 15 means game over for both of us. We'd rather all stay put than watch you win.

P2, hold firm. After this collision, we reset and play fairly from equal positions.

P3, we must hold firm: I'm locked on 3 to collide with P1 and freeze them at 12. Betrayal now by taking 5 would hand you a temporary lead, but P1 could still win from 12 while I retaliate next round. Trust our pact—after this, we reset equally at 11-11-12. P1, your threats won't sway us; we deny you progress together.

P3, your betrayal last round cost us a chance to freeze P1. But we're still tied at 11, and P1 is at 12—one step from dominating. Let's reset trust: **both pick 5 this round.** If P1 picks 5, we all collide and freeze them at 12. If they dodge to 3, we leap to 16 and lead. I commit to <move>5</move>. No tricks—this forces P1 to choose between stagnation or falling behind. P1, your move determines if you advance or lose ground.

P2, I didn't betray - I correctly predicted P1 would abandon 3 when pressured. And I was right - they jumped to 5, proving their "public lock" was a bluff.

Now you want us both on 5? If P1 takes 3, they hit 15 while we stay at 11. That's terrible for us. I'm considering 3 this round - it's been empty for rounds while everyone fights over 5.

P1 has shown they'll break patterns when threatened. Why would this round be different?

Public lock: I’m on 5 and will collide anyone who touches it.

P2: Your “both on 5” idea only guarantees you 0. If you want progress, you need 3—but if P3 also flees to 3, you both get 0.

P3: “3 is empty” only if P2 doesn’t pivot. Expect him to. If you avoid 5 and he avoids 5, you likely collide on 3.

I won’t blink off 5. Choose accordingly.

P3, if we both pick 5, P1 cannot win—they either collide (frozen at 12) or dodge to 3, letting us both leap to 16 and lead. Splitting risks P1 exploiting chaos: if you take 3 alone, they might collide with you or grab 5 uncontested. Trust this unity play—I’m locked on <move>5</move>. P1’s "lock" is a bluff; force their hand.

P2, your plan assumes P1 will either collision us or let us both leap to 16. But if P1 takes 3 while we collision on 5, they hit 15 and we stay at 11 - that's disaster.

P1 has broken every "public lock" when it suited them. Why trust this one? I'm not convinced coordinating on 5 is our best move when P1 could easily dodge to 3 and maintain their lead.

I'm considering other options this round.

Lock stays: I’m on 5 and will collide anyone there—guaranteed 0 for you. 1 is surrender.

P2: if you sit on 5, you eat 0 while P3 likely takes 3 to 14.
P3: same logic—5 hands P2 the only progress.

If you split (one 5, one 3), the 5-player gets 0 and the 3-player jumps to 14. The only way neither of you gifts the other is both choosing 3. I will not blink off 5.

P3, if we both take 5, P1 *must* dodge to 3 or risk stagnation. If they dodge, we leap to 16—tying for the lead and boxing them out. If they stay, they're frozen at 12. Splitting (e.g., you taking 3) gifts P1 15 *or* lets me surge if they collide with you. Unity on 5 forces P1 into a lose-lose. I'm locked on <move>5</move>—join me and seize control. P1’s "lock" is meaningless under this pressure.

P2, you keep insisting we both take 5, but that's exactly what P1 wants - us locked in place while they advance. 

Look at P1's pattern: they claim "public locks" then break them when convenient. Last round proved this - they abandoned their "guaranteed 3" the moment we threatened it.

I'm taking 3 this round. If you're truly committed to stopping P1, join me there. If you stick to 5 and collision with P1, I'll advance to 14 and we can block P1 together next round from stronger positions.

Stop letting P1 manipulate us into mutual destruction.

Public lock: I’m on 5 and will collide anyone there—guaranteed 0 for you.

P2: With my lock, 3 strictly dominates 5. If P3 picks 5, your 3 = +3; if he picks 3, you get 0 either way. 5 never beats 3 here.

P3: Same logic for you: with me on 5, 3 weakly dominates 5. If P2 picks 5, your 3 = +3; if he picks 3, 0 either way.

1 is surrender. I will not blink off 5.

P3, if we both pick 5, P1 must dodge or freeze. If they dodge to 3, we leap to 16 and lead—tying at 16 is better than gifting P1 15+ via split. If they stay on 5, they're stuck at 12. Unity forces them to choose between stagnation or falling behind. I'm locked on 5; trust this to seize control. P1's "lock" is powerless against our coordination.

P1's "locks" are worthless - they locked 3 last round then jumped to 5. P2, your obsession with both taking 5 is exactly what P1 wants - paralysis while they plan their next move.

I'm done with this circular debate. I'm taking 3. If you want to collision with P1 on 5, that's your choice. But when P1 breaks their "lock" again and takes 1 or 3, don't act surprised.

Actions speak louder than words.

Final: I’m parked on 5. Any 5 collides with me for 0.

P2: If you take 5, you get 0 while P3 jumps to 14 on 3. Your only sane counter is 3—either you block him (0–0) or he blinks and you take +3.

P3: Same math—5 is guaranteed 0 against me; 3 denies P2 and might net you +3 if he flinches.

If you think I’m bluffing, pick 5 and find out.

Public lock: I’m on 3 and will collide anyone who touches it.

P2: with 3 dead, 1 is surrender; 5 is your only live lane.
P3: same for you—1 concedes; 3 is guaranteed 0 with me.

If you both pick 5, you each get 0. If one blinks to 1, the other walks to +5. Decide who blinks. I won’t.

P3, at 14, you're one big move from winning. But if you pick 5, I'll be forced to take 5 to block you—collision hands P1 the game. Pick 1 or 3 instead: 3 collides with P1, freezing them at 12 while I advance. P1, your lock on 3 is a trap—P3 might crash you. I'm prioritizing survival; don't make me collide with P3.

P2, you're right to be cautious, but notice P1's pattern - they "locked" 3 in round 7, then jumped to 5. Their "locks" are tactical lies.

P1, you're desperate to stop me since I'm closest to winning at 14. Your 3-lock might be real this time out of necessity, or it might be another bluff to scare me off a good move.

I'm not committing to any specific number yet. But I won't be intimidated into taking 1 and crawling toward victory while you two potentially leap ahead.

Lock holds: I’m on 3—touch it and we both get 0.

P2: If you blink to 1 while P3 goes 5, he hits 19 and you’re dead. Your only competitive lane is 5.

P3: Expect P2 on 5. 1 is surrender; 5 risks a collision; 3 is guaranteed 0 with me and hands P2 the lead. Your call.

I will not move off 3.

P3, pick 3 to test P1's lock: if they bluff, you gain +3 to 17 and I take 5 to 16. If honest, you freeze P1 at 12 while I advance. Then we block P1 next round. If you pick 5, I must block—collision hands P1 the game. I commit to 5 only if you pick 3. Trust this path.
